# **1. OVERVIEW**

The main focus of this visual analytics assignment is to ...

uncover the impact of COVID-19 as well as the global economic and political dynamic in 2022 on Singapore bi-lateral trade (i.e. Import, Export and Trade Balance) by using appropriate analytical visualisation techniques learned in **Lesson 6: It's About Time**. Students are encouraged to apply appropriate interactive techniques to enhance user and data discovery experiences.

## **1.1 Singapore Exports**

Key export products -

43% machinery and equipment

19% petroleum

13% chemical products

8% misc manufactured goods.

7% oil bunkers

Main export partners -

China, 15%

China-Hong Kong 12%

Malaysia 11%

Indonesia 8%

United States 6%

Japan 5%

The top exports of Singapore are [Integrated Circuits](https://oec.world/en/profile/bilateral-product/integrated-circuits/reporter/sgp) (\$62.7B), [Refined Petroleum](https://oec.world/en/profile/bilateral-product/refined-petroleum/reporter/sgp) (\$27B), [Gold](https://oec.world/en/profile/bilateral-product/gold/reporter/sgp) (\$11.4B), [Packaged Medicaments](https://oec.world/en/profile/bilateral-product/packaged-medicaments/reporter/sgp) (\$9.9B), and [Gas Turbines](https://oec.world/en/profile/bilateral-product/gas-turbines/reporter/sgp) (\$9.24B), exporting mostly to [China](https://oec.world/en/profile/bilateral-country/chn/partner/sgp) (\$42.9B), [Hong Kong](https://oec.world/en/profile/bilateral-country/hkg/partner/sgp) (\$41.7B), [United States](https://oec.world/en/profile/bilateral-country/usa/partner/sgp) (\$27.6B), [Malaysia](https://oec.world/en/profile/bilateral-country/mys/partner/sgp) (\$22.9B), and [Indonesia](https://oec.world/en/profile/bilateral-country/idn/partner/sgp) (\$14.8B). ## **3.2 Import Data**

### **3.2.1 Import attributes data**

There are two (2) steps involve, which are import and inspect imported data set.

::: {.callout-tip collapse="true" appearance="simple" icon="false"}
## [**⇳ Usage of the code chunk below :**]{style="color:#3a9c88"}

[***read_xlsx( )*** - readxl -]{style="color:#d46e15"} to read Excel file into a tibble.

[***select( )*** - dplyr -]{style="color:#d46e15"} to retain columns specifically, "Data Series" and column names that contain "2019", "2020", "2021", and "2022". Include "2019" as "2019 Dec" is needed in order to include "2020 Jan" in the rate calculation.

[***slice( )*** - dplyr -]{style="color:#d46e15"} to remove the first row with "Total Merchandise Imports" for *trade_import* or "Total Merchandise Exports" for *trade_export*.

[***problems( )*** - readr -]{style="color:#d46e15"} to reveal any parsing errors when importing the Excel file.
:::

```{r}
#| code-fold: false
trade_import <- read_excel("data/merchandiseTrade_region.xlsx",
                           sheet = "T1",
                           range = cell_rows(10:129)) %>%
  select(`Data Series`, contains(c("2019","2020", "2021", "2022"))) %>%
  slice(-1) %>%
  select(-(4:13))
  
problems(trade_import)
```

```{r}
#| code-fold: false
trade_export <-  read_xlsx("data/merchandiseTrade_region.xlsx",
                           sheet = "T2",
                           range = cell_rows(10:101)) %>% 
  select(`Data Series`, contains(c("2019", "2020", "2021", "2022"))) %>%
  slice(-1) %>%
  select(-(4:13))

problems(trade_export)
```

## 3.3 Wrangle Data

### 3.3.1 Split variable

::: {.callout-tip collapse="true" appearance="simple" icon="false"}
## [**⇳ Usage of the code chunk below :**]{style="color:#3a9c88"}

[***separate( )*** - tidyr -]{style="color:#d46e15"} to split "Data Series" into 2 new fields "country" and "unit"

[***str_remove( )*** - stringr -]{style="color:#d46e15"} to remove parenthesis " ( ) " from the "unit" column.
:::

#### 3.3.1.1 Import data

```{r}
#| code-fold: false
trade_imports <- trade_import %>%
  separate(`Data Series`, c("country", "unit"),
           sep = ' \\(') %>%
  mutate(unit = str_remove(unit, '\\)'))
```

#### 3.3.1.2 Export data

```{r}
#| code-fold: false
trade_exports <- trade_export %>%
  separate(`Data Series`, c("country", "unit"),
           sep = ' \\(') %>%
  mutate(unit = str_remove(unit, '\\)'))
```

### 3.3.2 Split tables

The data consists of regional (unit consists of "Million Dollars") and country (unit consists of "Thousand Dollars") . Hence, two different objects will be created for different content by filter them accordingly.

::: {.callout-tip collapse="true" appearance="simple" icon="false"}
## [**⇳ Usage of the code chunk below :**]{style="color:#3a9c88"}

[***str_detect( )*** - stringr -]{style="color:#d46e15"} to separate data table at countries level and regions level.

[***slice( )*** - dplyr -]{style="color:#d46e15"} to remove "Germany, Democratic Republic Of" and "Yemen Democratic" that have 0 value for the entire 2 years.
:::

#### 3.3.2.1 Import data by "Thousand"

```{r}
#| code-fold: false
trade_importsK <- trade_imports %>%
  filter(str_detect(unit, "Thousand")) %>%
  select(-(unit))
```

#### 3.3.2.2 Import data by "Million"

```{r}
#| code-fold: false
trade_importsM <- trade_imports %>%
  filter(str_detect(unit, "Million")) %>%
  select(-(unit))
```

#### 3.3.2.3 Export data by "Thousand"

```{r}
#| code-fold: false
trade_exportsK <- trade_exports %>%
  filter(str_detect(unit, "Thousand")) %>%
  select(-(unit))
```

#### 3.3.2.4 Export data by "Million"

```{r}
#| code-fold: false
trade_exportsM <- trade_exports %>%
  filter(str_detect(unit, "Million")) %>%
  select(-(unit))
```

### 3.3.3 Remove "country" with 0 values

::: {.callout-tip collapse="true" appearance="simple" icon="false"}
## [**⇳ Usage of the code chunk below :**]{style="color:#3a9c88"}

[***slice( )*** - dplyr -]{style="color:#d46e15"} to remove "Germany, Democratic Republic Of" and "Yemen Democratic" that have 0 value for the entire 2 years.
:::

```{r}
#| code-fold: false
trade_importsK <- trade_importsK %>%
  slice(-20, -64)
```

```{r}
#| code-fold: false
trade_exportsK <- trade_exportsK %>%
  slice(-18, -62)
```

### 3.3.4 Pivot Tables

#### 3.3.4.1 Pivot imports table

::: {.callout-tip collapse="true" appearance="simple" icon="false"}
## [**⇳ Usage of the code chunk below :**]{style="color:#3a9c88"}

[***pivot_longer( )*** - tidyr -]{style="color:#d46e15"} to pivot data by reducing all year-month columns into a single column. This step is needed to compute the rate.

Arguments :

-   "cols" refers to all columns need to be reshaped except "country".

-   "names_to" is a new variable name, "temporary" to capture all the year-month of trades.

-   "values_to" is a new variable name, "import" or "export" to store all the traded values.

The code chunk is with reference to [cran.r-project](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/tidyr/vignettes/pivot.html)[^2].
:::

[^2]: Pivoting. cran.r-project.org. https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/tidyr/vignettes/pivot.html

```{r}
#| code-fold: false
import_pl <- trade_importsK %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = !country,
               names_to = "temporary",
               values_to = "import") %>%
  mutate(period = (lubridate::ym(temporary))) %>%
  arrange(country, period) %>%
  select(-temporary) %>%
  relocate(period)
```

```{r}
importM_pl <- trade_importsM %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = !country,
               names_to = "temporary",
               values_to = "import") %>%
  mutate(period = (lubridate::ym(temporary))) %>%
  arrange(country, period) %>%
  select(-temporary) %>%
  relocate(period)
```

Remarks :

When using arrange function without first mutate the value with ym function from lubridate package, the period will be sorted by the alphabetical order of the months' initial character. For example, 2020 Apr be displayed first, follow by 2020 Aug, 2020 Dec, 2020 Feb...

#### 3.3.4.2 Pivot exports table

```{r}
#| code-fold: false
export_pl <- trade_exportsK %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = !country,
               names_to = 'temporary',
               values_to = "export") %>%
  mutate(period = (lubridate::ym(temporary))) %>%
  arrange(country, period) %>%
  select(-temporary) %>%
  relocate(period)
```

```{r}
exportM_pl <- trade_exportsM %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = !country,
               names_to = "temporary",
               values_to = "export") %>%
  mutate(period = (lubridate::ym(temporary))) %>%
  arrange(country, period) %>%
  select(-temporary) %>%
  relocate(period)
```

### 3.3.5 Derive New Variables

#### 3.3.5.1 Derive regionals' trade balance between exports and imports

#### Step 1 - Join regionals level dataframes

```{r}
tradesM<- importM_pl %>% full_join(exportM_pl)
```

#### Step 2 - Derive variable

```{r}
trades_region <- tradesM %>%
  mutate(balance = export-import) %>%
  mutate(diff_balance = balance - shift(balance)) %>%
  mutate(rate = round(
    (diff_balance/shift(balance)),
    digits = 2))
```

#### 3.3.5.2 Derive countries' trade balance between exports and imports

#### Step 1 - Join countries level dataframes

```{r}
trades <- import_pl %>% full_join(export_pl)
```

#### Step 2 - Derive variable

```{r}
trades <- trades %>%
  mutate(balance = export-import) %>%
  mutate(diff_balance = balance - shift(balance)) %>%
  mutate(rate = round(
    (diff_balance/shift(balance)),
    digits = 2))
```

#### 3.3.5.3 Derive monthly imports differences 

```{r}
import_trim <- import_pl %>%
  mutate(diff_imp = import - shift(import)) %>%
  mutate(rate_imp = round(
    (diff_imp/shift(import)),
    digits = 2)) %>%
  filter(!period == "2019-12-01" & !period == "2019-11-01")
```

#### 3.3.5.4 Derive monthly exports differences 

```{r}
export_trim <- export_pl %>%
  mutate(diff_imp = export - shift(export)) %>%
  mutate(rate_imp = round(
    (diff_imp/shift(export)),
    digits = 2)) %>%
  filter(!period == "2019-12-01" & !period == "2019-11-01")
```

#### 3.3.5.5 Derive "year" and "month" variables

```{r}
trades_region$month <- factor(month(trades_region$`period`),
                              levels = 1:12, 
                              labels = month.abb, 
                              ordered = TRUE) 
trades_region$year <- year(ymd(trades_region$`period`))
```

## 4.2 Cycle Plot

### 4.2.1 Africa region

```{r}
#| code-fold: false
#| fig-height: 10
#| fig-width: 12
africa_plot <- ggplot()  +
  geom_line(data = africa,
            aes(x = year, 
                y = balance, 
                group = month), 
            colour = "black") +
  geom_hline(aes
             (yintercept = avg), 
             data = hl_africa, 
             linetype = 6, 
             colour = "red", 
             size = 0.5) + 
  facet_grid(~month) +
  labs(axis.text.x = element_blank(),
       title = "Trade balance with Africa region, Jan 2020-Dec 2022") +
  xlab("") +
  ylab("Trade Balance")

africa_plot
```
